abstract.text: A renderer for displaying a SceneKit scene in an existing Metal workflow or OpenGL context.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use this class when you want to add content rendered by SceneKit to an app that already renders other content by using Metal, OpenGL, or OpenGL ES directly. To provide content for a SceneKit renderer, assign a
For additional important methods and properties for working with SceneKit renderers, see

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
Information about the result of a scene-space or view-space search for scene elements.
A Core Animation layer that renders a SceneKit scene as its content.
A renderer for displaying a SceneKit scene in an existing Metal workflow or OpenGL context.
Creates a renderer with the specified OpenGL context.
Creates a renderer with the specified Metal device.
The timestamp for the next frame to be rendered.
Renders the scene’s contents in the renderer’s OpenGL context.
Renders the scene’s contents at the specified system time in the renderer’s OpenGL context.
Renders the scene’s contents at the specified system time in the specified Metal command buffer.
The scene to be rendered.
Creates an image by drawing the renderer’s content at the specified system time.
A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
Methods and properties common to the
, and
classes.
Methods your app can implement to participate in SceneKit’s animation loop or perform additional rendering.
A specification for augmenting or postprocessing SceneKit’s rendering of a scene using additional drawing passes with custom Metal or OpenGL shaders.
The common interface for SceneKit objects that support multipass rendering using
objects.
A view for displaying 3D SceneKit content.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
